title: 103_s26
content: The "American Jobs and Manufacturing Preservation Act of 1993" also includes provisions for the taxation of income of controlled foreign corporations attributable to imported property. The "American Jobs and Manufacturing Preservation Act of 1993" includes provisions amending the definition of foreign base company income in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It introduces a new category of income called imported property income, which is income derived from manufacturing, producing, growing, or other activities related to imported property. The "American Jobs and Manufacturing Preservation Act of 1993" introduces imported property income as a new category of income for controlled foreign corporations. This income is derived from activities related to imported property, including manufacturing, producing, growing, or other dispositions. The term "imported property" refers to property imported into the United States by the controlled foreign corporation or a related person. The term 'imported property' includes property imported into the United States by an unrelated person if it was sold by the controlled foreign corporation or a related person with the expectation of importation or use in other imported property. The term does not include property subsequently exported. The term 'imported property' refers to any property brought into the United States by a controlled foreign corporation or related person for use outside the country or as a component in other property sold internationally. The term 'import' includes entering or withdrawing from a warehouse for consumption or use. The term 'imported property' includes any property brought into the United States by a controlled foreign corporation or related person for use outside the country. The term 'import' involves entering or withdrawing from a warehouse for consumption or use. The term 'unrelated person' refers to any person not related to the controlled foreign corporation. The term 'foreign base company sales income' excludes any imported property income. The limitations on foreign tax credit for imported property income are separately applied. The tax code is amended to include imported property income as a separate category. Imported property income is defined as income received by a person that would qualify as such under section 954(h). The tax code is amended to include imported property income as a separate category under section 954(h). Amendments include changes to the look-thru rules and technical amendments related to imported property income. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years of foreign corporations starting after December 31, 1992, and to taxable years of United States shareholders in which or with which those foreign corporations' taxable years end. Subsection (c) amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1992.
